newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan CPC April profit up on falling crude costs.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan CPC April profit up on falling crude costs.

text.p: Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp said on Thursday its April pre-tax profit was T$2.003 billion, compared with a March pre-tax profit of T$884 million.
"Chinese Petroleum posted the April pre-tax profit mainly due to falling crude import costs during the period," a company official said.
Oil import costs averaged US$18.74 per barrel in April versus $20.26 in March, the firm said in a statement.

The company hiked its oil product prices by 2.97 percent on April 5 -- the second increase in four months -- to cover its accumulated budgetary deficit in its current fiscal year began from July 1996.
It raised its oil product prices nine percent on January 1.
The oil price hikes also helped boost its profits, the official said.
Chinese Petroleum had an accumulated budget deficit of T$15.745 billion between July 1996 and April 1997, the statement said.
